overview_metadata.overview_title: The Big and Small of It
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students use real-world data with large quantities as an introduction to scientific notation. They examine different ways technology displays large numbers. Students convert large and small numbers between scientific notation and standard form. They also compare numbers expressed in scientific notation.

overview_item_data_items: I can express numbers in scientific notation.
I can express numbers in standard form.
I can compare numbers written in scientific notation.
I can interpret scientific notation that you generate using technology.
You can use scientific notation to express very large and very small numbers.

The general form for scientific notation is <math><mi>a</mi><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></msup></math>. The variable <math><mi>a</mi></math>, with <math><mn>1</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, is the mantissa. The variable <math><mi>n</mi></math>, the exponent of 10, is the characteristic.
You can write, order, and operate with numbers using scientific notation.
Technology sometimes expresses values in scientific notation.
A number greater than 1 has a positive characteristic, and a number between 0 and 1 has a negative characteristic.

When comparing two numbers written in scientific notation, first compare the characteristics. The number with the larger characteristic is the larger number. If the characteristics are equal, then compare the mantissas. The number with the larger mantissa is the larger number.
